c: Vision, mission and goals are crucial pillars of any organisation as it strives for quality, performance and excellence. These pillars also let everyone know where the organisation is going in the future and how it will to get there. It is important to identify the vision, mission and goals of the EMC as this is what everyone who is employed by the EMC works towards. These three ‘pillars’ drive your behaviour and ethos of working.
The image below provides you with the current EMC Vision, Mission and Goals as well as other factors to consider of which we will cover as we go on through the course.

NURTURE FIRST relates to the values required of everyone working at the EMC. Values can be defined as ‘principles or standards of behaviour; one's judgement of what is important in life’. It is important to identify and relate to these values as they are a necessary requirement to adopt, not only for a harmonious working environment, but also for a working culture where everyone works together as a united team.
Develop people to their full potential through a culture of support.
Making the day-to-day enjoyable.
Applying your strong moral principles and honesty.
Due regard for the feelings, wishes, or rights of others.
Keep it simple, avoid over complicating.
Be determined to succeed.
What do the NURTURE FIRST values mean to you?

d.title: What do the NURTURE FIRST values mean to you?

c: The Jaguar Land Rover Customer First Principles were introduced in late 2016, aimed at building global respect and pride in our brand, and proving a platform for the continuous improvement in all aspects of behaviours of its workforce for today and tomorrow.
Customer First forms part of the organisation strategy where it seeks to drive customer satisfaction by embedding the ‘voice of the customer’ throughout the business.

Customers – present and future – are at the heart of everything we do. We are constantly investigating their current and potential needs to feed fresh ideas into our product planning cycle. We are always restless to be better and aim to continuously improve the customer experience at every touchpoint - Always putting the Customer First.

d:
We understand our customer’s needs.
We are flexible and create individual experiences that our customers love.

quote: Be flexible to my needs and respectful of my time.
I want an experience tailored to treat me as an individual, not a one-size-fits-all approach.

d: Making customers feel comfortable and at ease
Spending time getting to know each customer
Understanding and responding to each customer’s needs
Building a sense of belonging to the brand
Being personable and natural with customers

Customers tell us that they value their relationships with us. They like to be recognised and acknowledged if they are a regular customer. They value relationships which are genuine and professional. They expect that we will take the time to get to know them and respond to their individual requirements.
Offering help, but allowing the customer to browse the showroom without pressure
Running events to make customers feel part of the Brand
Referring to previous visits or conversations to build the relationship
Arranging the time and duration of the Handover to suit the individual’s needs
Taking the time to get to know other JLR teams to understand their issues and needs

We make the complex simple and respect our customers’ time.
We put in the effort so our customers don’t have to put in the effort.

quote: You put the effort in so I don’t have to.
My life is busy and complex so anything you can do to make things simpler and easier is appreciated.

d: Taking personal responsibility for getting things done
‘Closing the loop’ to ensure everything’s been completed
Changing ways of working to avoid a problem happening again
Making it effortless and simple for the customer

This Principle is about being proactive and taking personal responsibility for getting things done. It’s also about improving processes to enhance the service provided to the customer. The objective is to make it effortless and simple for the customer.

Customer research consistently identifies this behaviour as important for our customers. It’s about a mind-set which needs to be shared by everyone who represents Jaguar Land Rover, whether in an internal role or a customer facing role.
Examples of ‘Easy to Do Business With’ in action include:
Owning a customer problem and managing it through to resolution
Completing paperwork ahead of an appointment to speed things up for the customer
Simplifying key processes to make things easier for the customer
Focusing resources on resolving problems that cause customer dissatisfaction
Taking action to ensure that everything is available for a scheduled service or repair

We always keep to our word.
We’re there for our customers, when they need us.

quote: Do the things you say you’re going to do,
when you say you’re going to do them.

d: Doing what we say we’ll do, when we say we’ll do it
Following our processes flexibly  and thoroughly
Working as one team to serve the customer

This Principle brings together a number of ideas such as being thorough and consistent and carefully following key in a way that meets the customer’s needs. It also covers communicating with customers to keep them up to date and manage their expectations to make sure that we deliver our commitments.
These are the basic things that every one of us must get right in our day-to-day dealings with our customers.
Keeping customers updated on any delays
Responding promptly to requests for information
Consistently following agreed ways of doing things
Answering the telephone promptly and to the agreed standard
Working with other teams to meet customers’ needs

We’re genuine and open.
We nurture long term relationships built on trust.

quote: You are my trusted advisor.
You’re always open and have my best interests at heart.

d: Being transparent and sharing information openly
Respecting the customer’s views and requirements
Guiding the customer to the best solution for him/her
Making changes to improve things for customers
Apologising for problems and putting things right

This Principle is about treating customers with respect and giving them the solution that’s right for them. It’s about working in a way which is ethical and fair and doing the right thing, rather than what’s easiest. It’s about making decisions based on the needs of our customers, and being honest about problems and putting things right.
Publishing clear service pricing; explaining the service invoice to the customer
Proving a clear breakdown of the vehicle purchase price, including trade in
Advising the customer against options or services that do not meet their needs
Allowing the customer to make the decision without pressure
Being honest and straightforward about problems (e.g. delivery delays)

We make our customers smile.
We know it’s often the small things that make all the difference.

quote: Look after me and value me for today and for tomorrow.
Put a smile on my face, it’s often the small things that make a difference and the ones I remember and talk about.

d: Aiming to exceed each customer’s expectations
Spotting opportunities to surprise and delight the customer
Doing the little things that make it special
Feeling good about what we do for our customers
Delivering the ‘wow’ factor that people will tell their friends about

This Principle is about ‘going the extra mile’ to exceed customer expectations and deliver an outstanding customer experience. This is not necessarily about spending money on customer incentives or gifts, but about using our understanding of each customer’s personal situation to do the little things that will really add value for them.
By doing this, we are demonstrating that we know our customers, and that we are willing to put in extra time and effort to look after them.
Examples of ‘Make Me Feel Special’ in action include:
Walking a customer out to their car with an umbrella when it is raining
Showing ‘generosity of spirit’ in charging for small repairs
Offering small gifts (e.g. golf umbrellas) which reflect the customer’s interests
Making the Handover special and individual
Transferring luggage or shopping from the customer’s car to the courtesy car

c: What does Customer First mean to you? How do you think it relates to your working environment?

c: Operational Excellence is a workplace philosophy where problem solving, team work and leadership resort in ongoing improvements to an organisation. The principle behind Operational Excellence is that it is achieved by combining all elements of the LEAN Engine where they work simultaneously and in harmony with each other.

The concept of Operational Excellence links back to the JLR Vision, Mission and Goals especially where transforming the way in which engines are manufactured is desired to be recognised as the new global benchmark for excellence.
Striving for Operational Excellence is underpinned by everything you will cover throughout this course and ultimately taking this way of working into your immediate working environment.

d.title: 5S Workplace Organisation
body: Provides the foundation, the platform and underpins everything we work towards. Think of it like a sump. If the sump is not there, the engine will continue to work but not efficiently or sustainably. After a short time, the engine will fail. Therefore, we need a foundation in place which supports all components all of the time to maintain efficiency.

d.title: Workgroup Activities
body: Are the combination of all the things we do, how we work, how we apply process, how we apply procedure and how we continually strive to improve. It is also about the way we work and how the Nurture First principles can be applied to create a positive culture of working.

d.title: Total Productive Manufacturing
body: Is a shop floor driven improvement methodology where its purpose is to effectively manage plant assets which affects Operational Equipment Efficiency. It involves everyone in the organisation striving for the goal of Zero Accidents, Zero Breakdowns and Zero Defects.

d.title: Quality Operating System
body: Is a systematic and disciplined approach that uses standardised tools and practices to manage business and manufacturing outputs to achieve ever increasing levels of customer satisfaction.

d.title: Leadership (effective leadership practice)
body: Is extremely important where everyone has a role to play at all levels, especially where communication, vision, training, support, supervision, quality and values are intrinsic to teamwork and development.

d.title: Customer Focused (delivering results for the customer)
body: Ensures that all aspects of the organisation put customer satisfaction first as a measure of overall success. If our customers are satisfied with our performance and products, we have achieved our goals together.

d.title: Engineering Excellence (aligned Engineering and Operations)
body: Is achieved by combining innovation, engineering success, technical capability and practice with a focus on providing quality products through collaboration and communication across all levels.

d.title: Manufacturing Operating System
body: Is where our people, processes and equipment come together to add value to material and deliver quality products for our customers by ensuring we have the correct processes in place. Through continuous improvement strategies, we can bring new products to market, apply improvements and add new technologies to our manufacturing operations.

answers: It is a workplace philosophy where problem solving, team work and leadership resort in ongoing improvements to an organisation
It is a workplace philosophy where problem solving, team work and management resort in ongoing improvements to an organisation
It is a workplace philosophy where problem solving, leadership and management resort in ongoing improvements to an organisation

correct: That's correct!
Operational Excellence is a workplace philosophy where problem solving, team work and leadership resort in ongoing improvements to an organisation.
incorrect: Operational Excellence is a workplace philosophy where problem solving, team work and leadership resort in ongoing improvements to an organisation.

d.body: What are the component parts of Operational Excellence?

answers: 5S Workplace Organisation
Workgroup Activities
Total Productive Manufacturing
Quality Operating System
Leadership (effective Leadership practice)
Customer Focused (delivering results for the customer)
Engineering Excellence (aligned Engineering and Operations)
Manufacturing Operating System
Satisfying Customers
Total Quality System

correct: That's correct!
You have successfully identified the 8 components of Operational Excellence.
incorrect: Unfortunately you have not been able to identify the 8 components of Operational Excellence.

d: List the factors you consider are related to Operational Excellence and how you applied them in your previous role.

c: You can use the camera below to record any information from this activity.

A lean organisation understands customer value and focuses its key processes to continuously increase it. The ultimate goal is to provide perfect value to the customer through a perfect value creation process that has zero waste. Eliminating waste along entire value streams, instead of at isolated points, creates processes that need less human effort, less space, less capital, and less time to make products and services at far less costs and with much fewer defects, compared with traditional business systems. Companies are able to respond to changing customer desires with high variety, high quality, low cost, and with very fast throughput times. Also, information management becomes much simpler and more accurate.

d.caption: Single Piece Flow
content: One of the components of lean is Single Piece Flow (SPF). Instead of building up a stack of inventory between the steps in the process, the idea with single piece flow (also known as one piece flow), is to build at the pulse rate of customer demand.

d.caption: Push and Pull Production
content: A method of production control in which downstream activities signal their needs to upstream activities. Pull production strives to eliminate overproduction and is one of the three major components of a complete just-in-time production system.

In pull production, a downstream operation, whether within the same facility or in a separate facility, provides information to the upstream operation, often via a Kanban card, about what part or material is needed, the quantity needed, and when and where it is needed. Nothing is produced by the upstream supplier process until the downstream customer process signals a need. This is the opposite of push production.

d.caption: Flow
content: The objective of flow production is to drastically reduce product throughput time and human effort through a series of innovations. This includes consistent interchangeable parts so that cycle times can be stable for every job along an extended line, the line itself and the reconfiguration of part fabrication tasks so that machines are lined up in process sequence with parts flowing quickly and smoothly from machine to machine.

d.caption: Value Added Activities
content: Value Added Activities (VAA) are those activities associated with identifying value and non-value to the customer through a culture of continuous improvements in order to reduce non-value added processes.

quote: Spend an hour reducing or eliminating waste and non-value added activities,
not an hour debating what waste it is!

d.body: Which principle of LEAN drastically reduces product throughput time and human effort through a series of innovations?

answers: Value Added Activities
Pull Production
Flow
Single Piece Flow

correct: That's correct!
The objective of flow production is to drastically reduce product throughput time and human effort through a series of innovations.
incorrect: The objective of flow production is to drastically reduce product throughput time and human effort through a series of innovations.

c: Identify areas of Value and non-value in relation to your current experience.

d.title: Identify areas of Value and non-value in relation to your current experience.

c: You can use the camera below to record any information from this activity.

PDCA, sometimes called the “Deming Wheel”, “Deming Cycle”, or PDSA was developed by renowned management consultant Dr William Edwards Deming in the 1950s. Deming himself called it the “Shewhart Cycle”, as his model was based on an idea from his mentor, Walter Shewhart. Deming wanted to create a way of identifying what caused products to fail to meet customers' expectations. His solution helps businesses to develop hypotheses about what needs to change, and then test these in a continuous feedback loop.

d.title: Bike Simulation
body: In this exercise, your team will build two (2) prototype Motorbikes as part of your launch of your new company.
You will also present the new company name and logo for your ‘factory’.

c: In the note box provided, place in there your plan/overview of what you are going to do, this is your approach.
You should also place in there your thoughts on how it went and how it could be improved (from a LEAN perspective) after you have completed this activity.
Think about whether it went well or not. If it did not go well, what happened and what will you do differently next time?
Use the camera to photograph and capture the output of your bike simulation activity.

d: This is your chance to evaluate the learning from your perspective. This is a good way of identifying your strengths, relevant experience and areas of which you would like to improve knowledge or application of a specific subject.
As you go through the course, you can look back on each day and see if you have closed ‘the gap’ of the required knowledge, so you have an overview of how far you have come.
At the start of every day, there will be a Reflection session which is designed to refresh everyone’s knowledge of the previous day’s learning.
The session also gives you an opportunity to discuss what you took from the previous day.

With this in mind and in preparation for the following day, identify three things that you took from the session, (one take-away per box). You might want to start with how much knowledge you already had (knew & confirmed) or how much you didn’t know. What did you like (subjects)? Can you see how this is applied? What are you looking forward to?
After your Reflection session tomorrow, you can add information to your boxes of ‘Take-Aways’ relating to points you have received clarification on, or any further learning and thoughts you have.

c:
This is your opportunity to reflect and discuss the previous day’s learning and training.
This session continues from your evaluation ‘homework’ you did last night where you can discuss your main ‘take-aways’.
You can add to your three boxes any information and detail you feel appropriate at any time for you to draw on later or simply to look back at as the course continues.

d.title: Day 1 Take-Aways
body: Use the button below to navigate to the relevant performance evaluation page.
d.label: Day 1: Evaluate Performance

c: High performing teams are recognised as such because they consistently perform above expectation, exceed potential and continue to seek ways to improve. To achieve this status, they work towards the vision, the mission and the goals set by the senior leadership team within an organisation. They communicate effectively, share and learn from experience, they know the role they have to play at both team and individual level; they are also experts in their field. High performing teams are led, guided and supported at the appropriate levels of leadership and management with the aim of working towards the goal and in the context of JLR, Operational Excellence.
List all the factors you think are required of a High Performing Team.

d: When a new team comes together there is a process it will go through; this is called stages of team development. It is a process to describe the path most teams follow on their way to high performance. It is important to recognise the different stages the newly formed team find themselves in as it will assist greatly in working towards team harmony as efficiently and quickly as possible.Forming a team takes time, and members often go through recognisable stages as they change from being a collection of strangers to a united group with common goals. Bruce Tuckman 's Forming, Storming, Norming, and Performing model describes these stages.

d.title: Forming
body: In this stage, most team members are positive and polite. Some are anxious, as they have not fully understood what work the team will do. Others are simply excited about the task ahead. The leader will play a dominant role at this stage, because team members' roles and responsibilities are not clear. This stage can last for some time, as people start to work together, and as they make an effort to get to know their new colleagues.

d.title: Storming
body:
This is where people start to push against the boundaries established in the forming stage. This is the stage where many teams fail. Storming often starts where there is a conflict between team members' natural working styles. People may work in different ways for all sorts of reasons but, if differing working styles cause unforeseen problems, they may become frustrated.

Storming can also happen in other situations. For example, team members may challenge your authority, or jockey for position as their roles are clarified. Or, if you have not defined clearly how the team will work, people may feel overwhelmed by their workload, or they could be uncomfortable with the approach you are using. Some may question the worth of the team's goal, and they may resist taking on tasks. Team members who stick with the task at hand may experience stress, particularly as they do not have the support of established processes or strong relationships with their colleagues.

d.title: Norming
body: Gradually, the team moves into the norming stage. This is when people start to resolve their differences, appreciate      colleagues' strengths, and respect your authority as a leader. Now that your team members know one another better, they may socialise together, and they are able to ask one another for help and provide constructive feedback. People develop a stronger commitment to the team goal, and you start to see good progress towards it. There is often a prolonged overlap between storming and norming, because, as new tasks come up, the team may lapse back into behaviour from the storming stage.

d.title: Performing
body: The team reaches the performing stage, when hard work leads, without friction, to the achievement of the team's goal. The structures and processes that you have set up support this well. As a leader, you can delegate much of your work, and you can concentrate on developing team members. It feels easy to be part of the team at this stage, and people who join or leave will not disrupt performance.

d.title: Adjourning
body: Many teams will reach this stage eventually. For example, project teams exist for only a fixed period, and even permanent teams may be disbanded through organisational restructuring. Team members who like routine, or who have developed close working relationships with colleagues, may find this stage difficult, particularly if their future now looks uncertain.

d: <sub>Tuckman, B.W. (1965) 'Developmental Sequence in Small Groups,' Psychological Bulletin, Volume 63, June 1965.Tuckman, B.W. and Jensen, M.A.C. (1977) 'Stages of Small-Group Development Revisited,' Group Organization Management, Volume 2, Number 4, December 1977.</sub>
In the image below, you can see where, over time, how the stages of team development progresses.

What are your thoughts on Team Stages? Is this something you have considered before or witnessed? Can you relate to it?
Write in the box below your thoughts or anything you feel of importance which has been discussed in the session.

c: Use the camera to photograph and capture the output of the poster you have created (contributing factors of a High Performing Team).

Belbin suggests that, by understanding your role within a particular team, you can develop your strengths and manage your weaknesses as a team member, and so improve how you contribute to the team. Team leaders and team development practitioners often use the Belbin model to help create more balanced teams. Teams can become unbalanced if all team members have similar styles of behaviour or team roles. If team members have similar weaknesses, the team as a whole may tend to have that weakness. If team members have similar team-work strengths, they may tend to compete (rather than cooperate) for the team tasks and responsibilities that best suit their natural styles.

Knowing this, you can use the model with your team to help ensure that necessary team roles are covered, and that potential behavioural tensions or weaknesses among the team member are addressed. Most importantly it assists in self-awareness and helps us recognise behaviours in others of which we can appreciate better.

d.title: Shaper (SH)
body: Shapers are people who challenge the team to improve. They are dynamic and usually extroverted people who enjoy stimulating others, questioning norms, and finding the best approaches for solving problems. The Shaper is the one who shakes things up to make sure that all possibilities are considered and that the team does not become complacent. Shapers often see obstacles as exciting challenges and they tend to have the courage to push on when others feel like quitting. Their potential weaknesses may be that they're argumentative, and that they may offend people's feelings.

d.title: Implementer (IMP)
body: Implementers are the people who get things done. They turn the team's ideas and concepts into practical actions and plans. They are typically conservative, disciplined people who work systematically and efficiently and are very well organized. These are the people who you can count on to get the job done. On the downside, Implementers may be inflexible and can be somewhat resistant to change.

d.title: Completer-Finisher (CF)
body: Completer-Finishers are the people who see that projects are completed thoroughly. They ensure that there have been no errors or omissions and they pay attention to the smallest of details. They are very concerned with deadlines and will push the team to make sure the job is completed on time. They are described as perfectionists who are orderly, conscientious and anxious. However, a Completer-Finisher may worry unnecessarily, and may find it hard to delegate.

d.title: Coordinator (CO)
body: Coordinators are the ones who take on the traditional team-leader role and have also been referred to as the chairmen. They guide the team to what they perceive are the objectives. They are often excellent listeners and they are naturally able to recognize the value that each team member brings to the table. They are calm and good-natured, and delegate tasks very effectively. Their potential weaknesses are that they may delegate away too much personal responsibility, and may tend to be manipulative.

d.title: Team Worker (TW)
body: Team Workers are the people who provide support and make sure that people within the team are working together effectively. These people fill the role of negotiators within the team and they are flexible, diplomatic and perceptive. These tend to be popular people who are very capable in their own right, but who prioritize team cohesion and helping people get along. Their weaknesses may be a tendency to be indecisive, and to maintain uncommitted positions during discussions and decision-making.

d.title: Resource Investigator (RI)
body: Resource Investigators are innovative and curious. They explore available options, develop contacts, and negotiate for resources on behalf of the team. They are enthusiastic team members, who identify and work with external stakeholders to help the team accomplish its objective. They are outgoing and are often extroverted, meaning that others are often receptive to them and their ideas. On the downside, they may lose enthusiasm quickly, and are often overly optimistic.

d.title: Plant (PL)
body: The Plant is the creative innovator who comes up with new ideas and approaches. They thrive on praise but criticism is especially hard for them to deal with. Plants are often introverted and prefer to work apart from the team. Because their ideas are so novel, they can be impractical at times. They may also be poor communicators and can tend to ignore given parameters and constraints.

d.title: Monitor-Evaluator (ME)
body: Monitor-Evaluators are best at analysing and evaluating ideas that other people (often Plants) come up with. These people are shrewd and objective, and they carefully weigh the pros and cons of all the options before coming to a decision. Monitor-Evaluators are critical thinkers and very strategic in their approach. They are often perceived as detached or unemotional. Sometimes they are poor motivators who react to events rather than instigating them.

d.title: Specialist (SP)
body: Specialists are people who have specialised knowledge that is needed to get the job done. They pride themselves on their skills and abilities, and they work to maintain their professional status. Their job within the team is to be an expert in the area, and they commit themselves fully to their field of expertise. This may limit their contribution, and lead to a preoccupation with technicalities at the expense of the bigger picture.

c:
What are your thoughts on Team Roles? Can you relate to any of them? What skills and qualities do you bring to a team?
Write in the box below your thoughts, examples or anything you feel of importance relating to your contribution within a team.

If it is relevant you can list your strengths, your values and the role you undertook, in the box below.
You could also comment on where you have been a valued team member – when? What Role are you?
Reference
<sub>Belbin Associates (2012-15). 'Belbin Team Roles' [online].</sub>

Team meetings are important and an essential part of building a team and achieving the team's objectives. The meetings are an open opportunity to come together, reflect on progress and help each other. These meetings will help improve the general performance of the team and the productivity of individual members. Through team meetings, team members realise their importance. Project goals are always discussed in meetings.

As a team leader, you can explain to your team members how their tasks contribute to the overall goal. When tasks and goals are clear, employees are more motivated to work because they realise their importance in the company. Team meetings are held at the start of every shift where team leaders will brief their teams on yesterday’s performance, success, improvements, targets met and targets for the day. This is conducted at all levels of the business at different times of the day.
List the factors you consider important to be briefed in a team meeting and how you would conduct it as an agenda.

Team Boards play an important part in providing detail of captured data and information of which a team meeting could be centred around. They provide a structured approach of talking points and they are normally positioned close to the place of work, or at a key focal area where they can be easily gathered around. Team Boards can be displayed electronically or as a movable board (similar to the image below).

At the EMC, the Team Boards focus on the acronym SQDCPE of which the detail can be found in the graphic further below. Team Boards form part of the 5S workplace organisation where they fall within the Sustain element, they should be a way of life and not a one off activity.

d.title: Safety
body: Safety Calendar, Near Miss and Risk Assessments.

d.title: Quality
body: First Time Through (right first time), CCAR.

d.title: Delivery
body: Actual bikes delivered ‘v’s target (Customer order).

d.title: Cost
body: Cost to make bikes, tooling etc ...

d.title: People
body: Job Roles / Rotation Sheet, Versatility Matrix.

d.title: Environment
body: 5S Audit, 5S Cleaning Schedule.

c:
What are your experiences of where a Team Board has been used in your previous workplace?
If you have no previous experience, ask yourself - if Team Boards were introduced, would they have made a difference?

Change is inevitable, things change, we know that. We have all experienced change throughout our lives, some positive and some not so positive but one thing is certain, change will happen again. Change is required because something has happened of which requires adapting to. This happens to individuals, teams and organisations alike. If we do not change to evolve or make improvements, we will stand still and probably fail.

Other people or organisations will adapt and move forward, leaving us behind. Ultimately, if we fail to change or adapt, we will not be able to react to customer demands (because they change) and subsequently, the organisation’s vision, mission and goals. It is important to take the time to consider why change happens, how it starts, continues, and stops. This will help you to shape change so it produces the kind of innovations and improvements you want to happen, especially within an organisation which strives to continuously improve as part of its working culture.
So, what is Change?

quote: An act or process through which something becomes different.

d: It is important to recognise what happens to us as individuals whenever we have to undertake a change. The Kubler-Ross change curve provides an illustrative account of the process we go through.
Perhaps you can relate to this with certain feelings or behaviours you had through a period of change? How about when you moved house or changed a job? How about a new process you had to apply?
In the note boxes below, list in box 1 all the factors you think should be considered to make change as easy as possible. In box 2, place in there how you would implement those factors.

d.body: What is the definition of Change?

answers: ‘an act or process through which something becomes different’
‘an act or process through which people become different’
‘an act or process through which an organisation becomes different’

correct: That's correct!
It is an act or process through which something becomes different.

d.body: What is the reason for Change?

answers: To adapt to a new situation, evolve and continually improve
Keep on changing as that is what is needed
Continually change at every moment possible

correct: That's correct!
To adapt to a new situation, evolve and continually improve.
incorrect: The reason to change is to adapt to a new situation, evolve and continually improve. We should not be changing for change’s sake or because we have not changed in a while.

c: Policy Deployment is a method for ensuring that the strategic goals of a company drive progress and action at every level within that company. This eliminates the waste that comes from inconsistent direction and poor communication. Its importance derives from a management process that aligns - both vertically and horizontally - an organisation’s functions and activities with its strategic objectives. A specific plan (typically annual) is developed with precise goals, actions, timelines, responsibilities, and measures (sound familiar?).

In contrast to management by objectives, once the major goals are set, it should become a top-down and bottom-up process involving a dialogue between senior managers and project teams about the resources and time both available and needed to achieve the targets.

d.title: Hitting Targets
body: Achieving our goals and targets at every level is our contribution to company success.

c:
Our goals are set and aligned through a cascade process.
This process is a mechanism to cascade objectives from the Vision, Mission and Goals into executable objectives at every level of the organisation.

d: Whenever objectives are set, especially in relation to goals, they should be clear and reachable, and more importantly, SMART:

An organisation, when setting goals, targets or initiatives to improve, will probably not do it in one go. It will be spread over time as part of the annual plan. Remember, they must be achievable! When this is broken down to each area within the organisation it is up to that area to decide the best way to implement the plan and achieve the objectives, goals and targets. Like the organisation, the area will probably not do it in one go and again, spread it out over time.

An initiative to consider and one that has brought good levels of success is the philosophy of Marginal Gains. This concept was conceived by the then British Team cycling coach Sir Dave Brailsford where the central tenet was to introduce, incrementally, improvements of 1% to all areas of the cycling team, from selection of pillows to paint on the trucks. It changed the mind sets of everyone who was involved at every level of the team where they were empowered to make these small, but significant, improvements. It was not about doing it all in one go, it was a strategic approach to achieving the cycling team’s goals. Think back to the requirements of a High Performing Team! Above all else, it was a team effort.
In the image below, you can see how just 1% of improvements can make a difference.

With your previously conducted Bike Simulations in mind, In the note boxes below, list in box 1 all the areas in your Bike Simulations you could improve on, Marginal Gains applied.
In box 2, place in there the goals, or targets, you want to achieve in the next Bike Simulation.

answers: ‘a method for ensuring that the strategic goals of a company drive progress and action at every level within that company’
‘a method for ensuring that the areas of a company drive process and action at every level within that company’
‘a method for ensuring that the goals of a company drive progress and action at the production level within that company’

correct: That's correct!
Policy Deployment is a method for ensuring that the strategic goals of a company drive progress and action at every level within that company. The key word is strategic.

d.body: What is the Cascade process for?

answers: It is a mechanism to cascade objectives from the Vision, Mission and Goals into executable objectives at every level of the organisation.
It is a mechanism to set smart objectives from the Vision, Mission and Goals into executable objectives at every level of the organisation.
It is a mechanism to cascade objectives from the organisation’s plans into executable objectives at every level of the organisation.

correct: That's correct!
The cascade process is a mechanism to cascade objectives from the Vision, Mission and Goals into executable objectives at every level of the organisation.

c: 5S Workplace Organisation is the platform of the LEAN Engine, an integral component for achieving Operational Excellence. 5S makes processes transparent, so that an abnormality can be identified immediately; therefore 5S is also the basis for Visual Management and is ultimately the foundation step to continuous improvement techniques. It is a simple and methodical approach to organising the work space as a Five stage process, with each step starting with the letter “S” (hence the name 5S). The 5Ss are as follows:
The aim of the 5S Workplace Organisation is:

quote: To create the right environment and make processes more transparent so abnormalities can be identified immediately, becoming the basis for visual management.
A place for everything and everything in its place.

d: Team members should always start the process by identifying what product, tools and general clutter is not needed. This is achieved by following the “red tag process”, as the mechanism used to determine the functionality and usage of the components and parts on site.
Remember to take photographs of the area before any work is carried out
Identify the items not needed or not in a “designated area”

No Time should ever be wasted looking for parts or tools. All storage spaces, including floors should be labelled to enable quick identification of locations. To achieve this, proper signs, shelf markings and floor layouts will help the team to become more efficient by:
Reducing the time to collect parts or tools
Enable the operator to tell if the minimum number of parts has been reached or there are too many
Enabling the operator to tell at a glance if a part is missing (Shadow Boards)

Cleaning standards based on the best practices across all shifts are developed and moved forward. It is important to remember that the purpose of the 5S is to make ABNORMALITIES to STAND OUT. Teams should consider:
Baseline condition – what does ‘good’ look like?
Develop an inspection checklist document to define all the tasks required (AMs and Visual Standards)
A formal schedule and responsibilities for each of the tasks
Ensure training and tools are deployed as per particular requirements of the task
The only way to guarantee a standard outcome and attain the expected reliability is to ensure that:
Everyone carries out the exact same steps
Uses the same tools and parts
The Non-standard processes STAND-OUT (identification of abnormalities)
In one word, there is a requirement for STANDARDISATION. This process requires a documented procedure that specifies all the details required to achieve the tasks identified on the previous step.

5S should be a way of life, not a one off activity. The concept is on-going, so the team should be thinking about the next steps and the continuous improvement process. In this step, it is key the adherence to standards and the completion of regular audits. The 5S process must be regularly audited to ensure the standards are maintained.
5S process to be included in the leadership and supervisor process confirmation schedule
Extend process to other office and manufacturing areas
You will be shown a number of tools on screen over the course of 4 separate rounds
For each round, work through the checklist in front of you and tick off the tools as you find each one
You must tick off each of the tools in the order they are presented on your checklist
If you're within the classroom, call out when you've finished!

Visual management is an essential tool within the world of Lean and can be seen as the link between the data and the people. Visual management uses instinctive visual cues to make succinct, accurate information within a workplace available at all times to those who need to know it.

Effective visual management uses instinctive visual cues to communicate key information about a workplace ‘at a glance‘. Visual management is a way to communicate any and all information possible but you will most commonly find it as a way to display information about expectations, performance, standards and warnings. The key here is that through communicating this information visually, it requires no interpretation to understand.

quote: Make your workplace into a showcase that can be understood by everyone at a glance

c: The Benefits of Visual Management:

body: Work actually happens!
Creates Visual Thinkers.
The Physical work environment ‘speaks’.
Bottom Line Improvement.
Improved Safety.
Company-wide alignment.
Unity.

c: Ultimately, the aim of Visual Management is to communicate useful information quickly.

d.caption: Visual Management at the EMC – Walkways

c: List all the different types of visual ‘items’ you have noticed or think should be present at the EMC.

Visual displays and controls aim to increase the efficiency and effectiveness of processes and inspections by making the steps more visible. Information is communicated by using visual signals instead of texts or other written instructions.

If something is clearly visible or in plain sight, it is easy to remember and keep at the forefront of the mind. Another aspect of visual displays is that everyone is given the same visual cues creating consistency in the messaging.
List the differences between Visual Displays and Visual Controls.

d: Andons are systems to alert operators and managers about current problems in manufacturing. The system automates the information flow in case of problems. An Andon system usually consists of the actual Andon, sometimes called an Andon board.

An Andon Board is a visual management tool that highlights the status of operations in an area at a single glance and signals whenever an abnormality occurs. An Andon Board shows the location of concern to react/conduct a go-look see with easy to understand information ‘at a glance’ providing the associates (In particular, team leader) with information and current live status of the process they are running.
At the EMC, there are four types of Andon Boards used:
Andon Boards link to multiple parts of the LEAN Engine especially within Workgroup Activities as part of achieving Operational Excellence.

d.caption: Assembly Area Andon board type A (Zonal)
content: Shows the hall, zone, time and is live information.

d: A red box shows you a station is down
A yellow box shows you a station has a warning
A red station number shows you the station has been deselected and is in bypass
A yellow box around a station number shows you the station has lost communication with the MES

content: Write in here all other factors the Assembly Zonal Andon Board tells you.

d.caption: Assembly Areas Andon board type B (Leg)

d: ‘Actual’ is the number of good engines that have left the last station in the last zone
A yellow light shows you a call button has been pressed
‘Transport’ shows you the number of conveyors down on each zone
Red solid shows us a station is down
Red flashing shows us maintenance are in attendance at a station

content: Write in here all other factors the Assembly Leg Andon Board tells you.

d.caption: Assembly Areas Andon board type C (Line)
content: Board types B&C show the same information and displayed to reflect Leg (B) and Line (C).
Write in here all other factors the Assembly Line Andon Board tells you.

d.caption: Machining Areas Andon board type D (Line)
content: Show us the status of Gantries (G) and Machines (M).

d: A red box indicates a Machine or gantry is down
A red operation number shows you a machine within that operation has been deselected and is in bypass
A yellow box indicates a Machine or gantry is has a warning
A yellow box around an operation number means that operation has lost communication with MES

content: Write in here all other factors the Machining Line Andon Board tells you.

c: Standardisation is the process of developing and implementing standards where a standard is the best, safest and easiest way, to achieve and maintain a defined quality level.

Standards can help organisations reduce time, effort and money. It can help to assess the processes, allowing organisations to take steps to increase efficiency and become more profitable. It can help to provide a reliable benchmark against which performance can be judged. Standardisation provides a solid foundation upon which to develop new technologies and to enhance existing practices.

Standardised work is one of the most powerful but least used KAIZEN/Lean tool. If current best practices are documented, standardised work forms the baseline for kaizen (continuous improvement). Once the standard is formed it is further improved and helps to form new standard and so on. Therefore, improving standardised work is a never-ending process.

Through the standardised processes we implement, a continuous pursuit of perfection, applying standardisation, provides the foundation to build upon. As you can see from the diagram, the formed standard provides the platform of which we use to look at how it can be further improved. Once the process (to improve) has been applied, we should have moved forwards (realising an improvement through applying PDCA). Once consolidated, we go again. This is Continuous Improvement (Kaizen).
Make a list of what you think standardisation seeks to achieve and the consequences of not applying standardisation principles.

Standard Work is a process or procedure specific to your operation that describes the activities necessary to complete tasks in accordance with industry regulations, laws or even just your own standards for running the organisation. Any document that is a “how to” falls into the category of Standard Work. In a manufacturing environment, the most obvious example of Standard Work is the step by step production line procedures or process used to make products by well trained staff. Standard Work defines expected practices in all businesses where quality standards exist.
The aim of Standard Work is to achieve efficiency, quality output and uniformity of performance, while reducing miscommunication and failure to comply with industry regulations.

As typical Standard Work procedures Quality Process Sheets (QPS) are used on a daily basis and in conjunction with the Work Element Sheet (WES); both form an integral part of workgroup activities in order to prove or disprove errors or quality within a process.

A Versatility Matrix is a simple visual tool to aid in the management, control & monitoring of skill Levels. It displays all tasks & skills required to work in an area or team, it displays all current team members (providing current competency/ability levels for each task) and importantly, it is a simple tool to aid resource planning.
The need for a Versatility Matrix is as follows:

body: Establish skills required in an area or team.
Visually shares information.
Quickly identifies current available skills and future requirements.
A day-to-day planning tool utilising skills where they are most needed.
A planning tool to organise adequate cover for holiday & sickness.
Highlights training needs for the most important resource...employees.
Increases flexibility by allowing people to master a broad range of skills.

answers: A Versatility Matrix is a simple visual tool to aid in the management, control & monitoring of skill Levels.
A Versatility Matrix is a spreadsheet to aid in the control & monitoring of skill Levels.
A Versatility Matrix is a simple visual tool to control the management of skill Levels.

correct: That's correct!

incorrect: The correct answer is - A Versatility Matrix is a simple visual tool to aid in the management, control & monitoring of skill Levels.

answers: It displays all tasks & skills required to work in an area or team, it displays all current team members (providing current competency/ability levels for each task) and importantly, it is a simple tool to aid resource planning.

It displays all personal requirements to work in an area or team, it displays all current team members (providing current competency/ability levels for each task) and importantly, it is a simple tool to aid resource planning.

c: TAKT is the German word for the baton that an orchestra conductor uses to regulate the tempo of the music. TAKT time may be thought of as a measurable beat time, rate time or heartbeat.

In Lean, TAKT time is the rate at which a finished product needs to be completed in order to meet customer demand. If a company has a TAKT time of five minutes, this means that every five minutes a complete product, assembly or machine is produced off the line because on average a customer is buying a finished product every five minutes.
Described mathematically, TAKT time is:

Available time for production
÷
Required units of production

TAKT ensures that all of the capacity in a business is planned, utilized and meets overall customer demand. By and large, TAKT will help to deliver the right product (RP) at the right time (RT) in the right quantity (RQ) to the customer. You can achieve RP, RT, and RQ without implementing TAKT; however, this could lead to much waste of resource and machine.

d: Cycle time is the total time from the beginning to the end of your process, as defined by you and your customer. Cycle time includes process time, during which a unit is acted upon to bring it closer to an output, and delay time, during which a unit of work is spent waiting to take the next action. Basically, it is the balance of what we need to do (TAKT time) and what we can do (Cycle time).

Cycle time should not be confused with Lead time. Lead time is measured by elapsed time (minutes, hours, etc.), whereas Cycle time is measured by the amount of time per unit (minutes/customer, hours/part, etc.).
Lead time is the total time it takes from receiving an order to delivering an item.
In the box below, calculate whether the organisation can keep up with demand based on the following criterion:

What is the Cycle Time?
Can we keep up with demand?

answers: TAKT time is the rate at which a finished product needs to be completed in order to meet customer demand.
TAKT time is the rate at which a product should be completed in order to meet customer demand.
TAKT time is the time it takes to finish a product based on the process and needs of customer demand.

correct: That's correct!
TAKT time is the rate at which a finished product needs to be completed in order to meet customer demand.
incorrect: TAKT time is the rate at which a finished product needs to be completed in order to meet customer demand.

answers: Cycle Time is the total time from the beginning to the end of your process, as defined by you and your customer.
Cycle Time is the rate from the beginning to the end of production, as defined by you and your customer.
Cycle Time is the total time from of the process, as defined by the customer.

correct: That's correct!
Cycle Time is the total time from the beginning to the end of your process, as defined by you and your customer.
incorrect: Cycle Time is the total time from the beginning to the end of your process, as defined by you and your customer.

answers: Lead time is the total time it takes from receiving an order to delivering an item.
Lead time is the total time it takes from production to delivering an item.
Lead time is the available time it takes from receiving an order to delivering an item.

correct: That's correct!

You can discuss these points, and others, in the next reflection period.

This is your opportunity to reflect and discuss the previous day’s learning and training. This session continues from your evaluation ‘homework’ you did last night where you can discuss your main ‘Take-Aways’.
You can add to your three boxes, any information and detail you feel appropriate at any time for you to draw on later, or simply to look back at as the course continues.

d.title: Day 3 Take-Aways
body: Use the button below to navigate to the relevant performance evaluation page.
d.label: Day 3: Evaluate Performance

c: Line and Work Balancing is the redistribution of the workload across relevant stations within an operating line in order to maximise efficiency and production as close to TAKT time as possible.

The flow of products along the operating line requires a balanced amount of time at each station. By observing the line, Value Added Events (VAE), Non-Value Add (NVA) and Waste can be identified and plotted.

From this information collected at each station, the total time it takes to produce a ‘product’ can be calculated and plotted. The visual representation of each station will show whether or not a station is operating above (inefficient), at (efficient) or below (exceeding) TAKT time. If any of the stations within the operating line has a combination of all three scenarios, this will indicate that the Line will require balancing and workload redistributed.
The ultimate aim is to meet customer demand.
The image here provides a simplistic overview of how Line and Work Balancing can be applied.
List all the factors you consider to be either VAE, NVA or Waste within an operating line based on your experience so far.

The visual representation of the work activities relating to a station can be plotted by using a Balancing Board (a visual tool to aid the balance of the work assignments allocated to the operators at each station on the line). Every work element in the assembly of an engine has a standard time allocated to it. These work elements are represented by scaled blocks which can be stacked on top of each other. The blocks are colour coded to identify VAE work (Green), NVA work (Yellow) and Waste (Red). A straight line is drawn across the chart to show the TAKT time.

d.body: What is Line and Work Balancing?

answers: Line and Work Balancing is the redistribution of the workload across relevant stations within an operating line in order to maximise efficiency and production as close to TAKT time as possible.
Line and Work Balancing is the plotting of the workload across relevant stations within an operating line in order to maximise efficiency and production as close to Cycle time as possible.
Line and Work Balancing is the redistribution of Waste across relevant stations within an operating line in order to maximise efficiency and production as close to TAKT time as possible.

correct: That's correct!
Line and Work Balancing is the redistribution of the workload across relevant stations within an operating line in order to maximise efficiency and production as close to TAKT time as possible.
incorrect: Line and Work Balancing is the redistribution of the workload across relevant stations within an operating line in order to maximise efficiency and production as close to TAKT time as possible.

d.body: What is the main aim of applying Line and Work Balancing techniques?

answers: The main aim of applying Line and Work Balancing techniques is to meet customer demand.
The main aim of applying Line and Work Balancing techniques is to exceed customer demand.
The main aim of applying Line and Work Balancing techniques is to meet customer demand as close as possible.

correct: That's correct!
The main aim of applying Line and Work Balancing techniques is to meet customer demand.
incorrect: The main aim of applying Line and Work Balancing techniques is to meet customer demand.

s.n: Bike Simulation 4 – Ex In the Balance

title: Bike Simulation 4 – Ex In the Balance

d.title: Bike Simulation
body: In this exercise, the workflow of the production line is required to be balanced effectively based on the timings captured from the previous exercise.

c: In the note box provided, place in there your approach to how you balanced the line.
Use the camera to photograph and capture the output of your bike simulation activity.

Process Confirmation is a method that provides managers and leaders with an adequate level of confidence in process quality, repeatability and consistency. It involves going to where the work is actually being done and confirming that the way it is being done works and is in accordance with the organisation's policies and procedures (or not).

Overtime, systems and procedures will be tested for convenience, time or knowledge by personnel, it is human nature. The leader’s role is to guide personnel back into the system and explain why deviation from process is bad for the business.

The conduct of Process Confirmation provides an opportunity to confirm that the processes and systems are in place, in use and understood. It also a chance to develop the skills and knowledge of individuals through coaching as well as an opportunity for the Leadership Team to engage with the shop floor on a regular basis.
It is not about finding or attributing blame to an individual or team for a process/system not working.

The conduct of Process Confirmation is applied by following a process in itself – Process Confirmation Flow.
The flowchart below indicates the process to follow:
List the benefits of applying Process Confirmation.

T Cards are used in the application of Process confirmation where they have up to 3 questions on the topics of LEAN, Quality & Safety (1 for associate, 2 for Team Leader). They also highlight where process confirmation is positioned within our Operational Excellence Lean Engine.
List in the boxes below, based on your learning in this lesson, When Process Confirmation is undertaken (schedule), How it is implemented and by Whom.

answers: Process Confirmation is a method that provides managers and leaders with an adequate level of confidence in process quality, repeatability and consistency.
Process Confirmation is a method that provides leaders with an adequate level of confidence in process, repeatability and consistency.
Process Confirmation is a method that provides managers and leaders with an adequate level of confidence in process quality, leadership and consistency.

correct: That's correct!
Process Confirmation is a method that provides managers and leaders with an adequate level of confidence in process quality, repeatability and consistency.
incorrect: Process Confirmation is a method that provides managers and leaders with an adequate level of confidence in process quality, repeatability and consistency.

answers: Process Confirmation provides an opportunity to confirm that the processes and systems are in place, in use and understood by all personnel.
Process Confirmation provides an opportunity to confirm that the processes and systems are in place, in use and understood by the management team.
Process Confirmation provides an opportunity to confirm that the processes and systems are in place, in use and understood by the Leadership Team.

correct: That's correct!
Process Confirmation provides an opportunity to confirm that the processes and systems are in place, in use and understood by all personnel.
incorrect: Process Confirmation provides an opportunity to confirm that the processes and systems are in place, in use and understood by all personnel.

c: Standardised Work Confirmation (SWC) is a method that safely combines Man, Machines & Materials to produce the Quality, Cost & Delivery required irrespective of who carries out the task.
It is a “GO – LOOK – SEE” tool using QPS & WES to confirm the process, adherence to the process, ensure safety of the associate and identifying the quality of the product.
List all the benefits the application of Standardised Work Confirmation brings and the impact if it is not applied.

d: SWC is applied by following the steps on the SWC Document.
Complete the SWC document while working through the key steps provided.
Ensure the SWC is a two way communication, talk to the Associate (Off line if possible). Understand concerns and issues within the process and what the options to improve are.
Log the details of any actions required including a target date for closure.

SWC Documentation can be found in Assembly on the Toblerone and archived once complete. Team Leaders’ SWC schedule is also on the Toblerone. In Machining the SWC Sheet is kept on the Toblerone and the Team Leaders’ SWC Schedule is kept in the Pod.
List the do’s and don’ts when applying SWC.

Standardised Work Confirmation Process Flow is a flowchart relating to how SWC is applied end-to-end. All in all, there are seven steps to undertake to ensure it is conducted correctly. The image below provides the flowchart representation of the Process Flow.

In the box below, write down your main observation points you noted during the visit to a live assembly production line. You can also write in here other observations identified during the classroom discussion after the live assembly visit.

answers: Standardised Work Confirmation is a method that safely combines Man, Machines & Materials to produce the Quality, Cost & Delivery required irrespective of who carries out the task.
Standardised Work Confirmation is a process that safely combines Method, Machines & Materials to produce the Quality, Cost & Delivery required irrespective of who carries out the task.
Standardised Work Confirmation is a method that safely combines Man, Machines & Materials to produce the Quantity, Cost & Delivery required irrespective of who carries out the task.

correct: That's correct!
Standardised Work Confirmation is a method that safely combines Man, Machines & Materials to produce the Quality, Cost & Delivery required irrespective of who carries out the task.
incorrect: Standardised Work Confirmation is a method that safely combines Man, Machines & Materials to produce the Quality, Cost & Delivery required irrespective of who carries out the task.

d.body: What supporting documents are used when conducting Standardised Work Confirmation?

answers: QPS and WES
QPS and TPM
QAS and WES

correct: That's correct!
QPS and WES are used to confirm the process, adherence to the process, ensure safety of the associate and identifying the quality of the product.
incorrect: QPS and WES are used to confirm the process, adherence to the process, ensure safety of the associate and identifying the quality of the product.

c: What were your 3 ‘Take-Aways’ from today? Relate back to your learning and Ex In the Balance for inspiration, especially regarding the Line and Work Balancing and whether it worked or not.
You can discuss these points, and others, in the next reflection period.
